name: Batik
desc: The art of painting that uses canting as a tool for painting. Canting itself is a small bowl-shaped tool made of copper and has a carat or monong, with a stem made of bamboo or wood which can be filled with wax (wax) as a material for painting. This canting can create a collection of lines, dots or checks which ultimately form patterns. These patterns then become decorative variations in batik art with their respective meanings. Batik, which is spread throughout almost all of Indonesia, has various decorative forms that differ from one another.

patterns.name: Sido Mukti
patterns.desc: Classic batik is typical of palace clothing originating from the Javanese language. The name "Sido Mukti" comes from the words 'sido' which means to be, or continually, and 'mukti' which means noble and prosperous. Sido Mukti motif batik means continually being noble and prosperous or living well. This batik is made using natural sogan dye and is usually worn as clothing in traditional wedding ceremonies during receptions or mahalgyan events. This batik motif is worn by the bride and groom and is also called sawitan (a pair). By wearing batik with the Sido Mukti motif, it is hoped that the bride and groom will experience happiness throughout their lives.

patterns.name: Sido Luhur
patterns.desc: Batik Sido Luhur is a type of palace batik originating from the Yogyakarta and Surakarta Palaces. The Sidoluhur batik motif is usually worn by the bride on her wedding night at the Surakarta Palace. The Sidoluhur batik motif has a nobility philosophy, namely looking for material and immaterial aristocrats. Material nobility can be defined as the fulfillment of all physical needs achieved through hard work in harmony with the profession. What is meant by intangible aristocrats is aristocrats in the form of spirit, language and actions. Apart from that, the Sidoluhur batik motif is also very important for performances and can be a role model for the community.

patterns.name: Sekar Jagad
patterns.desc: Batik Sekar Jagad comes from Yogyakarta. This motif has a meaning that comes from the Javanese words 'sekar' and 'jagad'. 'Sekar' which means flower or flower, and 'Jagad' which means world or universe. So the Sekar Jagad motif depicts the diversity of the world of flowers and plants, symbolizing a happy heart because a daughter or son has found a soul mate. There are also those who think that the Sekar Jagad motif actually comes from the word 'kar jagad' which is taken from Javanese (kar: 'peta', jagad: 'world'), so this motif also symbolizes diversity throughout the world.

patterns.name: Parang
patterns.desc: Batik Parang is a batik motif that has been around for a long time. The word 'parang' comes from the Javanese word 'pereng' (meaning: 'slope'), which is described as a curve resembling an ocean wave. Parang patterned batik is also known as sword or keris patterned batik. The machete eye symbol is in the shape of the letter 'S' which symbolizes power, strength and enthusiasm that never goes out like a burning fire. This is why during the Mataram kingdom in Kartasura, machete-patterned batik could only be worn by kings, rulers and knights such as princes and senopati. Therefore, batik with the Parang motif is also called forbidden batik because ordinary people cannot wear it.

patterns.name: Lereng
patterns.desc: The Lereng motif batik has a pattern similar to the Parang batik. The only difference is the presence of a 45 degree diagonal line between the Parang motifs. You can also find the Slope motif with a simple pattern, namely a row of narrow diagonal lines and full of small ornaments. In ancient times, this motif could only be worn by the royal family. The philosophical meaning behind Lereng batik is as a symbol of purity and strength.

patterns.name: Ikat Celup
patterns.desc: Batik Ikat Celup is also known as tie-dye. The technique used in this activity is the technique of tying cloth knots which are then colored to produce unique and varied designs. If there is only a small part you want to color, you can use a brush. Different ways of folding, rolling, knotting, filling or dyeing textiles will produce different patterns and colors. This motif has become a fashion trend in Indonesia.

patterns.name: Cenderawasih
patterns.desc: Batik Cenderawasih comes from Papua. This motif has a meaning as its name suggests, showing a clear identity, namely the bird of paradise motif. This batik motif is very special because for the Papuan people, the bird of paradise is a type of bird from heaven. The philosophical meaning of the Cenderawasih motif represents the Papuan people's admiration for the bird of paradise. The Cenderawasih pattern also represents Papua's artistic expression of the God-given universe. Papuan people express the beauty of the bird of paradise in batik designs.

patterns.name: Lasem
patterns.desc: Batik Lasem is characterized by patterns and colors that are more striking than other types of batik. Lasem batik is often made with pink bird, bamboo or lion motifs. The characteristic of this motif is the result of a combination of Chinese and Javanese culture, especially the Javanese coast. Over time, the Lasem batik motif developed, featuring butterfly designs with a variety of flora and fauna or other creative combinations of shapes and patterns while maintaining its specific distinctive color, namely a striking combination of brown, dark yellow and purple.

patterns.name: Kawung
patterns.desc: Kawung is a Batik motif originating from the island of Java. Kawung is shaped like a palm fruit and is arranged at the four corners in a square shape. The philosophy contained in the palm tree, from the tips (tips of the leaves) to the roots, is very beneficial for human life. The meaning of Kawung batik itself includes perfect self-mastery, a pure heart without any desire to boast.

patterns.name: Mega Mendung
patterns.desc: Mega Mendung adalah is Batik Cirebon which combines Islamic and Chinese elements. Evidence of this can be seen in the cloud paintings on plates from China installed on buildings at the Gunung Jati site. The cloud shape was processed by Cirebon craftsmen to produce a unique style. This motif is related to Taoist ideology originating from China which believes that clouds are a symbol of a higher world, a vast and transcendent world. The Mega Mendung motif features a layered color palette consisting of five to seven layers of colors with meanings from the Islamic religion. The number five is the pillar of Islam and the number seven is the sky through which the Prophet Muhammad SAW passed.

patterns.name: Tambal
patterns.desc: This batik comes from Solo. In ancient times, cloth with Patch motifs was believed to speed up the healing process for the sick. Batik with a Patch motif is widely used as a blanket for sick people. Batik Tambal is also said to have a magical effect, namely it can block various evil influences. Philosophically, batik with a Patch motif is also expected to increase enthusiasm. With enthusiasm, new hope will emerge, and healing can occur quickly. Tambal Batik also teaches people to always improve themselves so that they can have a better life.

patterns.name: Gentongan
patterns.desc: Batik Gentongan is a type of written batik from Madura that is of good quality and highly upholds Madurese traditions. It is called Gentongan batik because the coloring process is done by soaking the batik cloth in a barrel during the manufacturing process. This aims to add color and remove remaining wax, resulting in a color that lasts for years. Gentongan batik designs and patterns are the result of each batik maker's imagination. The origin of Gentongan batik comes from fishermen's wives who wanted to give souvenirs to their husbands who were returning from fishing. Batik is given to husbands as a blessing and a manifestation of the wife's devotion to her husband. From there, they can also contribute to the family's economy by selling batik cloth.

patterns.name: Truntum
patterns.desc: Batik Truntum is batik that comes from Solo. Truntum means growing again, developing, blossoming, or moving towards progress (usually in love). In traditional Javanese wedding ceremonies, this motif is often used by the parents of the bride and groom. The use of the Truntum motif symbolizes parents who will guide and guide the bride and groom towards a new life, especially married life which is full of twists and turns. Family life will last forever with love that always grows and develops (truntum).

patterns.name: Tumpal
patterns.desc: The Tumpal motif comes from Betawi and is used quite often. This triangular Tumpal pattern symbolizes balance and harmony between humans, the universe and the other world (God). This motif is associated with a human lifestyle which can be in harmony with nature or spirituality. The Tumpal motif teaches a person to seek and live a balanced life between the worldly and the hereafter.

patterns.name: Semen
patterns.desc: The Batik Semen name comes from the Javanese word 'semi' which means to grow or develop. Specifically, spring means buds or growing parts of a plant. In accordance with its meaning, Semen motif batik has the meaning of the philosophy of life that blossoms, grows, or develops. In the cement motif there are other images in the form of mountains or Meru, Garuda, wings, temples and dragons. This motif is also one of the prohibited motifs of the Yogyakarta Palace.

name: Songket
desc: Cloth woven using threads of gold, silver and other colors using the stitching technique, namely inserting the gold or silver threads under the intersections of the warp threads (longitudinal threads) and weft threads (transverse threads). Areas that are famous for songket crafts include West Sumatra, Palembang in South Sumatra, Bali, Central Lombok, and abroad such as Malaysia and Brunei.

patterns.name: Nago Basaung
patterns.desc: The Nago Basaung motif depicts the shape of dragons facing each other, as if depicted in a state of fighting with each other. Also known as the Nago Betarung motif, the name Nago Basaung is rooted in the unified structure of the dragon motif which forms a circle which is believed to contain positive meaning in people's lives. The dragon symbol is believed to be a source of strength, advice, images and ancestral history of the Palembang people. Songket Nago Basaung is often used as complementary clothing at weddings in Palembang society because dragons are believed to be a symbol of magical, spiritual, goodness, prosperity, kindness and wisdom values.

patterns.name: Nampan Perak
patterns.desc: The Nampan Perak motif comes from the word tray, which is a place used to deliver all the needs of a king or sultan, such as delivering food and letters. This motif is significant as a depiction of the glory and obedient attitude of the royal servants. In ancient times, Silver Songket Trays were worn by noble families who usually used gold thread in almost all of the basic cloth.

patterns.name: Pucuk Rebung
patterns.desc: The Pucuk Rebung motif comes from the form of bamboo shoots or bamboo, all parts of which are fully functional, from the roots, stems and leaves can be used. Apart from that, bamboo plants were previously used as royal fences so this motif has a philosophical meaning, namely that those who wear it will be protected from obstacles and trials and as a symbol of prosperity.

patterns.name: Subahnale
patterns.desc: The Subahnale motif comes from the word "Subhanallah" which means Glory be to Allah or Almighty God. There is a philosophical meaning to the word Subahnale which is associated with a high level of complexity in the making process, weavers must be patient and surrender to God so that the songket making process runs smoothly. The characteristic of this motif is that it looks like a ceplok flower and is surrounded by a honeycomb-shaped geometric motif called a cage.

patterns.name: Bungo Cino
patterns.desc: The Bungo Cino motif comes from the word Bungo which means flower and Cino comes from Chinese which means gold. The gold thread on this songket reflects wealth and luxury. This cloth was first created as a symbol of high social status and has become an inseparable part of Palembang culture. The motifs used in songket bungo cino are inspired by the surrounding nature and local culture. For example, the jasmine pattern symbolizes beauty and purity, while the rose pattern symbolizes freedom and natural beauty. The use of bright and contrasting colors is also a characteristic of Bungo Cino songket, for example red, yellow, green and others represent various values, such as courage, nobility and fertility. Making Songket Bungo Cino requires a lot of patience and skill, the process begins with weaving gold or silver thread using a traditional loom. The coloring process often uses natural ingredients such as noni leaves or tree bark. Physically, the Palembang Bungo Cino Songket is made from gold and silver threads woven using a special technique. However, more than just decorated cloth, this Songket conveys important messages about life and Palembang's cultural values. This cloth is widely used in traditional ceremonies, weddings, cultural festivals and other important events in the city of Palembang. We as an easy generation must preserve the rich cultural heritage and revive the most important traditions.

types.name: Songket Palembang
types.desc: Typical Palembang songket cloth with floral, geometric, decorative and animal motifs.

types.name: Songket Bali
types.desc: Typical Balinese songket cloth often has traditional motifs such as wayang, dance and other Balinese arts.

types.name: Songket Minangkabau
types.desc: Minangkabau songket cloth actually displays teachings, wisdom values and natural philosophy.

types.name: Songket Lombok
types.desc: Lombok songket cloth usually comes in natural colors from plants ranging from stems, roots, leaves and fruit with large motifs that almost fill the cloth.
